sgcool_label_text:This pair of red lacquered hexagonal holders would be used on altars as a joss stick container. They site on a brass base which is decorated with images of bats. Bats are symbols of happiness.\r\n\r\nThis item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan
 Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857
 Singapore – d. 7 February 1918
 Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose
 formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island
 which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.

metadata.title_text: Pair of joss stick holders Joss stick holders
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a pair of joss stick holders. The body is a hexagonal cylinder, painted red. The holder sits on a wider hexagonal brass base. The base is decorated with images of bats.
metadata.subject_terms_1: altar components Peranakan religious ceremonies ceremonial objects incense sticks
metadata.subject_terms_2: Incense burners and containers Altars Peranakan (Asian people) Rites and ceremonies Ceremonial objects
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This pair of red lacquered hexagonal holders would be used on altars as a joss stick container. They site on a brass base which is decorated with images of bats. Bats are symbols of happiness.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.
